title: A Repeated Segment on the Mouse Y Chromosome Is Composed of Retroviral-Related, Y-Enriched and Y-Specific Sequences
abstract: We report the isolation and characterization of two recombinant clones containing DNA derived from the Y chromosome of the C57BL/10 inbred mouse strain. Both clones were isolated from a lambda phage library derived from a partial EcoRI digest of C57BL/10 male DNA using the murine retrovirus M720. Characterization of these clones showed they were derived from a repeated segment present on the C57BL/10J Y chromosome that contains sequences related to a previously unknown group of murine retroviruses, as well as repetitive sequences found elsewhere in the genome. In addition, one clone contained a sequence, designated YB10, that is unique to the Y chromosome and present in approximately ,500 copies on the C57BL/1 OJ Y chromosome. Analysis of SOUTHERN blots containing DNAs prepared from females and males of representative species from four subgenera of Mus probed with pYBlO and the J'LTR from one of the Y-associated retroviruses (MuRVY) revealed that, with the exception of a single fragment observed in both female and male DNA of Mus saxicola, hybridization to pYBlO was observed only to male DNA of the species Mus spretus, Mus hortulanus, Mus musculus, Mus domesticus and Mus abbotti. In addition, the pattern and intensity of hybridization to YBlO and the MuRVY-LTR indicated that sequence of divergence was followed by amplification of Y chromosome sequences containing YBlO and MuRVY. The divergence and amplification occurred separately in each of the ancestral lineages leading to M. spretus, M. hortulanus, M. abbotti, M. musculus and M. domesticus. We suggest that acquisition and amplification of DNA sequences by the mammalian Y chromosome has contributed to its evolution and may imply that the mammalian Y chromosome is evolving at a faster rate than the rest of the genome. Orono, Maine 04469.

abstract.text: We report the isolation and characterization of two recombinant clones containing DNA derived from the Y chromosome of the C57BL/10 inbred mouse strain. Both clones were isolated from a lambda phage library derived from a partial EcoRI digest of C57BL/10 male DNA using the murine retrovirus M720. Characterization of these clones showed they were derived from a repeated segment present on the C57BL/10J Y chromosome that contains sequences related to a previously unknown group of murine retroviruses, as well as repetitive sequences found elsewhere in the genome. In addition, one clone contained a sequence, designated YB10, that is unique to the Y chromosome and present in approximately ,500 copies on the C57BL/1 OJ Y chromosome. Analysis of SOUTHERN blots containing DNAs prepared from females and males of representative species from four subgenera of Mus probed with pYBlO and the J'LTR from one of the Y-associated retroviruses (MuRVY) revealed that, with the exception of a single fragment observed in both female and male DNA of Mus saxicola, hybridization to pYBlO was observed only to male DNA of the species Mus spretus, Mus hortulanus, Mus musculus, Mus domesticus and Mus abbotti. In addition, the pattern and intensity of hybridization to YBlO and the MuRVY-LTR indicated that sequence of divergence was followed by amplification of Y chromosome sequences containing YBlO and MuRVY. The divergence and amplification occurred separately in each of the ancestral lineages leading to M. spretus, M. hortulanus, M. abbotti, M. musculus and M. domesticus. We suggest that acquisition and amplification of DNA sequences by the mammalian Y chromosome has contributed to its evolution and may imply that the mammalian Y chromosome is evolving at a faster rate than the rest of the genome. Orono, Maine 04469.

body_text.text: T HE Y chromosome is unique among mammalian chromosomes because it is the only chromosome that does not contain loci necessary for the survival of an individual. It does, however, contain loci necessary for the survival of each species-those involved in testis determination and possibly sperm formation. In 1914 H. J. MULLER hypothesized that the X and Y chromosomes of Drosophila originated from a pair of homologous autosomes. If, as suggested by OHNO (1967), the mammalian X and Y chromosomes also evolved from homologous chromosomes, extensive DNA sequence variation as well as rearrangements and deletions have occurred repeatedly in the evolution of the Y chromosome. In fact, if synapsis is indicative of sequence homology, the only area of extensive homology still shared by the mammalian X and Y chromosomes is within their pairing region. Recent data support this conclusion (reviewed by GOODFEL-LOW, DARLING and WOLFE 1985) .

Several laboratories have begun investigations into the evolution and function of the mammalian Y chromosome by analyzing DNA clones that detect Y chro-mosome-derived restriction fragments on SOUTHERN blots. As is the case for the human Y chromosome (see review by GOODFELLOW, DARLING and WOLFE 1985; SILVER et al. 1987) , the mouse Y chromosome contains Y-specific repeats (BISHOP et al. 1986; NISHIOKA and LAMOTHE 1986) as well as Y-enriched repeats (LAMAR and PALMER 1984; NALLASETH et al. 1983 ; NALLA-SETH and DEWEY 1986) and retroviral-related sequences (PHILLIPS et BLATT et al. 1983) . In addition, the mouse Y chromosome contains a concentration of Bkm-related Wanded krait Einor satellite) sequences UONES and SINCH 1981) located near its centromere (SINGH and JONES 1982; EPPLEN et al. 1982) .

We have begun an investigation into the evolution and function of the mammalian Y chromosome by isolating and analyzing DNA clones from the mouse Y chromosome. To identify Y chromosome-derived DNA sequences, we hybridized retroviral-derived probes to SOUTHERN blots containing restriction enzyme digested DNA from females and males of inbred mouse strains. T w o types of retroviral-related sequences were identified in male DNA: a 5.5-kb EcoRI fragment that hybridized to an amphotropic retroviral LTR (long terminal repeat) and four EcoRI fragments that hybridized to a xenotropic-type C virus called M720 (PHILLIPS et al. 1982) . The male-specific M720related sequences are of special interest because they are present on the Y chromosome in at least 100 copies, unlike the single copy male-specific LTR fragment. The multiple copy nature and unique size of these male-specific fragments provided us with the opportunity to efficiently isolate Y chromosome-derived "720-related clones from a C57BL/10 male library.

Here we report the isolation and characterization of two mouse Y chromosome-derived clones containing M72O-related sequences. We present evidence that these clones are derived from a repeated segment that contains a sequence specific to the Y chromosome, designated YBlO, several sequences enriched on the Y chromosome, a previously undescribed Y-linked retrovirus, designated MuRVY (K. W. HUTCHISON and E. M . EICHER unpublished data), and at least two ubiquitous repeats. We also present evidence that approximately 5% of the C57BL/10J Y chromosome is composed of a 7.4-kb EcoRI fragment containing both YB 10 and MuRVY-related sequences.

We speculate on the evolution of YBlO and MuRVY in the Y chromosome of the genus Mus. We suggest that both sequences became associated with the Y chromosome of species in the subgenus Mus following divergence of this subgenus from other Mus subgenera. Divergence and subsequent amplification of the region of the Y chromosome containing these sequences occurred in the species M . spretus, M. hortulanus, M. musculus, M. domesticus and M . abbotti. These findings are discussed in relation to the evolution of the mammalian Y chromosome.

Mice: Pedigreed pairs of mice of the C57BL/lOJ inbred strain were obtained from the Foundation Colony of T h e Jackson Laboratory. Frozen spleens or spleens and kidneys from female and male mice representing the following Mus species were obtained from Litton Bionetics (Kensington (BONHOMME 1986) . We favor the position that M. domesticus and M. musculus are separate species (HUNT and SELANDER, 1973; SAGE, WHITNEY and WILSON, 1986; .

The actual mice or the founders used to establish a laboratory colony of the mice used in these studies were captured in the following locations: M. saxicola, India (Mysore); M. pahari, Thailand (Tak Prov.; Lampang); M. minutoides, Kenya (Nairobi); M . caroli, Thailand (Chonburi Genomic DNA isolation: Mouse genomic DNA was prepared from frozen spleen or spleen and kidneys using the method OfJENKINS et al. (1982) or from frozen h e r using a modification of the method of BLIN and STAFFORD (1 976). T o ensure no cross contamination of DNA during isolation, the glass homogenizing tubes as well as glass rods used for winding out high molecular weight DNA were acid treated in 4 N HCI for 2 hr and rinsed thoroughly before use.

Isolation of M720-related clones: The EcoRI partialdigest library of C57BL/10 male DNA cloned into Charon 4A (WEAVER et al. 1981) was screened by the procedure of BENTON and DAVIS (1977) using a pBR322 clone of M720 viral DNA (PHILLIPS et al. 1982) . T h e amplified library contained approximately 1.8 X lo6 independent recombinants with an average insert size of 16 kb. A total of 2.2 X lo5 phage were screened under the DNA hybridization conditions given in PHILLIPS et al. (1982) .

Preparation of DNA and radiolabeling of probes: Recombinant phage DNAs were prepared using the small lysate method of LEDER, TIEMEIER and ENQUIST (1977) or the glycerol gradient preparative method of MANIATIS, FRITSCH and SAMBROOK (1982) . T h e DNA was digested with restriction enzymes and appropriate fragments were isolated from low melting temperature agarose gels (WEIS-LANDER 1979) and used as probes or subcloned into plasmid pBR325 by standard procedures (MANIATIS, FRITSCH and SAMBROOK 1982) . These probes were labeled to a specific activity of >2 X 10' cpm/pg with [ ( U -~~P I -~C T P (Amersham) by the nick translation method of RICBY et al. (1977) .

T h e 305-bp EcoRI/PstI fragment (designated as YB10) derived from the XY6 clone was subcloned into pBR325. This subclone, pYB10, was labeled with [(U-~*P]-~CTP to a specific activity of >0.5 X 10' cpm/pg using the T 4 DNA Polymerase Labeling System supplied by Bethesda Research Laboratories, Inc.

A BglII/XhoI fragment representing part of the LTR of the murine retrovirus designated MuRVY (Murine Repeated Virus on the _Y chromosome) (K. W. HUTCHISON and E. M. EICHER unpublished data) was isolated from the 7.4kb EcoRI fragment contained in clone XY6 and subcloned into the BamHI-Sal1 site of M13mp8. This subclone, pMuRVY-LTR, was labeled using a modification of the M 13 dideoxy sequencing method. Single-stranded DNA was isolated from an infected JM 103 culture and annealed with the M13 15-base primer supplied in the BRL, Inc. MI3 Sequencing System. Labeled DNA was synthesized by adding 1 PI each of 0.1 M DTT, 10 mM dATP, 10 mM dGTP, 10 mM dTTP, 100 pCi of [a-"PI-dCTP, 2 U of the Klenow fragment of DNA polymerase I, and 10 U of EcoRI. The reaction was incubated at 34" for 20 min, followed by a nonradioactive chase of 1 p1 10 mM dCTP for 20 min and terminated with the addition of 1 PI 0.25 M EDTA and 80 p1 TE. The labeled DNA was purified on a Sephadex G-50 minicolumn and used as a hybridization probe.

Gel electrophoresis and hybridization conditions: Ten micrograms of genomic DNA or 1 pg of cloned DNA was digested with restriction enzymes under conditions supplied by the manufacturer (Bethesda Research Laboratories). DNAs were separated by electrophoresis in 1% agarose (Seakem, FMC Corp.) gels. T h e DNAs were blotted to nitrocellulose (Schleicher & Schuell) by the method of SOUTHERN ( 1 975) or to nylon filters (Zeta-Probe, Bio-Rad 1,aboratories) with 0.4 M NaOH (REED and MANN 1985) . Nitrocellulose filters were baked at 80" in vucuo. Both nitrocellulose and nylon filters were prehybridized at 65" for 3-4 hr with 4 X SSCP (1 X SScP = 121 mM NaCI, 15 mM Nay citrate, 15 mM NanHP04, 5 mM NaHyP04), 10 X Denhardt's solution (0.2% Ficoll, 0.2% polyvinylpyrollidone, 0.2% bovine serum albumin), 1 % SDS and 0.1 mg/ nil denatured sonicated salmon sperm DNA. The hybridization conditions were 65" for 18-20 hr in the same solution with the addition of 0.2% SDS and 1-5 X 10" cpm/ml of "'P-labeled probe. After hybridization, the filters were washed extensively at 65" with 4 X SSC, 0.1% SDS with a final rinse of 0.1 X SSC at room temperature. Filters containing DNAs from wild-derived mice were washed extensively at 65" as above or with 0.1 X SSC, 0.1% SDS. Using the method of SHAW et al. (1984) . the stringency of the washes of filters hybridized with YBIO, which contains a 39% G-C content (DNA sequence EMBL accession number X12900), was calculated to be 98% at 0.1 X SSC and 79% at 4 X SSC. Autoradiography was performed using Kodak XAR-5 x-ray film and Du Pont Cronex intensifying screens, unless otherwise noted in the figure legends. Exposure times ranged from 1 hr for some cloned DNA experiments to overnight or 3-4 days for genomic DNA filters.
Restriction fragment sizes were extrapolated from lambda Hind111 fragments using a Gel Pad Program (KILH Biosoft, Inc.) and a HiPad digitizer (Houston Instrument) on an Apple IIe computer.

Estimating copy number of the 7.4-kb EcoRI repeated fragment containing YBlO and MuRVY sequences: Two sepmte experiments were conducted to estimate the number of copies of the 7.4-kb EcoRI fragment present in the C.57BL/1 OJ Y chromosome. In the first experiment amounts of XY6 DNA equivalent to 500, 100, 50 or 10 copies per haploid genome were added to 10 pg of genomic C57BL/ lOJ female DNA. These DNAs were digested with EcoRI, separated by electrophoresis in a 1 % agarose gel, blotted onto nitrocellulose and probed with pYBIO. Ten micrograms of EcoRI-digested male C57BL/10J DNA were included in two lanes of the gel as controls. T h e second experiment was conducted exactly as the first, except the experimental lanes contained XY6 DNA equivalent to 800, 600, 500,400, 200, 100 and 50 copies per haploid genome added to 10 pg of genomic C57BL/10J female DNA. In both experiments the intensity of hybridization of the 7.4kb EcoRI YBlO male DNA fragment was compared to the hybridization intensity of the 7.4-kb EcoRI fragment derived from XY6 that had been added to female DNA. A Bio-Rad model 620 densitometer was used to screen the x-ray films.

Identification and characterization of Y chromosome-derived clones: Twelve plaques representing both strong and weak hybridization signals were randomly selected for further investigation from a total of 149 M72O-positive plaques. DNAs were prepared from each of these phage clones as small phage lysates and tested for possible Y chromosome origin using two criteria: the clone must (1) contain one or more M72O-positive EcoRI restriction fragments identical in size to known C57BL/10 male-specific M720 EcoRI fragments (Figure l ) , and (2) contain restriction fragments that hybridize more intensely when probed with "P-labeled male DNA than with '*P-labeled female DNA. Of the 12 clones tested, two met both criteria: XY6, which was strongly positive when hybridized with M720, and XY45, which was weakly positive when probed with M720. Further characterization of each clone, including a restriction map and the region of M720 homology, is presented in Figure 2 and below.

As seen in Figure 3A , XY6 contains a 1 1.7-kb insert consisting of two EcoRI fragments that hybridize to M720 and are identical in size to two of the C57BL/ 10 male-specific EcoRI M720 related fragment (7.4 kb and 4.3 kb). When EcoRI digests of XY6 were probed with nick translated female vs. male mouse DNA, both fragments hybridized less intensely with female DNA ( Figure 3B ).

The second clone, XY45, contains a 17.5-kb insert consisting of five EcoRI fragments (4.3, 8.0, 0.2, 2.0 and 3.0 kb). M720 hybridizes only to the 4.3-kb EcoRI fragment, a fragment identical in size to one of the -Identification of Y chl-onlosotne-derived clones. A, SOLTHERN blot of 1 p g BcoRl digested DNA from clone XY6 and XY45 probed with M720. The dots indicate the fragments in each clone identical in size to Mi20 positive EcoKI fragments in C57BL/ 101 male DNA. B. SOUTHERN blot containing 1 p g ofBcoRl digested DNA from clones XY6 and XY45 hybridized to ' l-P labeled male ;~nd female DNA (C57BL/lOJ). The filters were first probed with nick translated female DNA and exposed to x-ray film for three days. Labeled DNA was then stripped from the filters by washing twice at room temperature with 0.1 X SSC. 0.1 % SDS preheated to 95". The same filters were then probed with nick translated nlale DNA. C57BL/lO male-specific M72O-related EcoRI fragments ( Figure 3A) . When EcoRI digests of XY45 were probed with nick translated female mouse DNA, hybridization was observed to the 4.3-, 8.0-, 2.0-and 3.0-kb EcoRI fragments. When the same blot was reprobed with nick translated male mouse DNA, more intense hybridization occurred to the 4.3-kb, 8.0-kb and 2.0-kb EcoRI fragments than was observed using female DNA. The relative intensity of hybridization observed for the 3.0-kb EcoRI fragment appeared similar when probed with female or male DNA (Figure 3B) .

Although these results support the hypothesis that the XY6 and XY45 clones are of Ychromosomal origin, either or both of these cloned sequences could reside elsewhere in the genome because the assay using nick translated genomic DNA reflects the concentration of repeats in the probe (genome) rather than the exact DNA sequence being tested (SHEN and MANIATIS 1980). For example, an individual copy of an M720related sequence, regardless of chromosomal origin, would yield a stronger hybridization signal when probed with total male DNA vs. female DNA because there are more copies of M72O-related sequences in the male genome. In addition, the presence of one or more ubiquitous sequences, such as B1, B2, or Line elements, within any fragments would obscure differences between female and male DNA. Thus, for example, although there appears to be a similar number of 3.0-kb EcoRI fragments present in the female and male genomes, there may be more copies in the male genome if this fragment contains a ubiquitous repeated sequence. T o determine whether these clones were of Y chromosomal origin, EcoRI restriction fragments were isolated from XY6 and XY45 and subcloned into pBR325. Each subclone was then used to probe SOUTHERN blots of EcoRI digested C57BL/10J male and female DNA. As seen in Figure 4 , both EcoRI fragments from XY6 hybridize to fragments present in both sexes as well as fragments specific to or found in greater copy number in male DNA, again consistent with the potential Y chromosomal origin of XY6. The definitive proof of the Y chromosomal origin of XY6 was obtained when an EcoRIIPstI fragment derived from XY6 ( Figure 2 ) was used as a hybridization probe to genomic male and female DNAs. This fragment, designated YBlO, hybridized only to male DNA even after long exposure times ( Figure 5 ). From these results we conclude that XY6 is of Y chromosomal origin because it contains a sequence present exclusively in male DNA.

All of the EcoRI fragments isolated from XY45 hybridized to fragments present in both sexes as well as fragments specific to or enriched in male DNA (Figure 4) , an observation consistent with the potential Y chromosomal origin of XY45. The greater intensity of hybridization observed when male rather than female DNA is used was especially evident for the 2.0kb RcoRI fragment derived from XY45. Additional evidence for the Y chromosomal origin of XY45 was obtained by comparison of its 4.3-kb EcoRI fragment to that of the 4.3-kb EcoRI fragment present in XY6. Both 4.3-kb EcoRI fragments produce the same hybridization pattern when used to probe SOUTHERN blots of EcoRI-digested male and female DNA (only data for XY6 shown) ( Figure 4 ) and the restriction maps for both fragments are identical using six different restriction enzymes (Figure 2 ). All of this data is consistent with the Y chromosomal origin of XY45.

Other regions of homology shared by XY6 and hY45: SOUTHERN blots containing EcoRI-digested DNA derived from each of the pBR325 subclones (the EcoRI fragments) from XY6 and XY45 were probed with nick translated DNA from each clone to identify other regions within XY6 and XY45 that share sequence homology. As seen in Table 1 and as mentioned above, the 7.4-kb EcoRI fragment of XY6 shares sequence homology with the 4.3-kb EcoRI fragment of XY6 and XY45 based on the presence of M72O-related (MuRVY) sequences in both. In addition, the 4.3-kb EcoRI fragments derived from both XY6 and XY45 share homology with the 8.0-kb EcoRI fragment of XY45. This homology is not due to M720related or MuRVY sequences because neither M720 nor the 7.4-kb EcoRI fragment hybridizes to the 8.0kb EcoRI fragment. The reason for this cross hybridization is unknown at this time. After long exposure hybridization of the 0.2-kb EcoRI fragment from XY45 was detected with the 8.0-kb EcoRI fragment from XY45, indicating these fragments share a limited sequence homology. Finally, the 3.0-kb EcoRI and 2.0-kb EcoRI fragments from XY45 did not hybridize with any other EcoRI fragments generated from XY6 or XY45. Because both the 3.0-kb EcoRI and 2.0-kb EcoRI fragments hybridize with nick translated female DNA, we conclude that each contains repetitive sequences located elsewhere in the genome.
Determining the copy number of the 7.4-kb EcoRI

The designation for each probe desrrihes the specific KroRl fragment it contains and the I a n~l ) d a clone from which it was derived: e.g., pY6/ 7.4 contains the 7.4-kh F h R I fragment from XY6. An (*)designates those fragnwnts ohserved only after long exposure. FIGURE 5.-Y-specific sequence. SOUTHERN blot containing 10 pg of EcoRl digested C57BL/lOJ female and male DNA probed with an CroRI/Pstl subclone (pYB IO) isolated from the 7.4-kh EcoRl fragment from XY6. Even after a long exposure, no hybridization w a s observed to female DNA. Films were exposed at -70" with intensifying screens. A, Exposure time one day: B, exposure time 7 daVS. repeated segment containing YBlO and MuRVY sequences: To estimate the number of copies of the 7.4-kb EcoRI segment containing YBlO and MuRVY sequences that are present on the Y chromosome of C57BL/1 OJ mice, w e determined the number of copies of YBlO on the Y chromosome in two separate experiments. In experiment 1 (data not shown), the intensity of hybridization of the most abundant size class of EcoRI fragments (7.4 kb) observed in male DNA was equivalent to that observed in female DNA containing between 100 and 500 copies of XY6, and estimated by densitometry to be 450 copies. In experiment 2 (shown in Figure 6 ), the number of copies of the 7.4-kb EcoRI fragment present in the male genome was equivalent to that observed in female DNA containing between 500 and 600 copies of XY6, and determined to be 550 copies by densitometry. Assuming that all (500 copies, the average of experiments 1 and 2) of the 7.4-kb EcoRI YB10-related fragments are present in the repeated sequence identified by XY6, a minimum estimate of the amount of the C57BL/10J Y chromosome occupied by this repeated sequence can be calculated. T h e mitotic length of the mouse Y chromosome represents approximately 2.5% of the haploid mouse genome (reviewed by Committee on Standardized Genetic Nomenclature for Mice 1972) and the haploid mouse genome consists of 2.7 X 10" kb (LAIRD 197 1). Using these figures, we estimate that 5.5% [(500 copies X 7.4)/(0.025 X 2.7 X 10'' kb) X 1001 of the C57BL/1 OJ Y chromosome is composed of the repeated segment of DNA contain- abbotti. The filters were washed at both 79% and 98% stringency with no detectable differences noted in hybridimtion pattern. Fragment sizes of Ianlbda Hind111 markers are indicated. Films were exposed for 3 days at -70" with intensifying screens.

ing YBlO and MuRVY-related sequences. Figure 8A and a tabulated summary of this data is provided in Table 2 . A number of conclusions can be made from this data. First, the Y chromosome of these five species can be distinguished using YB 10 because each displays a unqiue pattern of hybridization, which includes the presence/absence of EcoRI fragments plus differences in the relative hybridizing intensity of a number of EcoRI fragments. Second, M. musculus and M. domesticus appear to contain more copies of YB10-related sequences in their genome than do M. abbotti, M.

hortulanus or M. spretus, suggesting that either their Y chromosomes contain more copies of YB 1 O-related sequences or the YB10-related sequences share greater homology with the YBlO sequence isolated from the XY6 clone, which is of C57BL/10 origin. T h e possibility of a difference in homology would not be surprising because C57BL/10J contains a M. musculus Y chromosome as seen from its pattern of hybridization with pYBIO, a result also in agreement with BISHOP et al. (1986) . Evidence that the difference noted between species is due to copy number and not sequence homology was obtained by comparing the patterns of hybridization using lower stringency conditions for hybridiztion (data not shown): no additional pYBl O-hybridizing fragments were observed for any of these five species at lower stringency than at higher stringency. We conclude from this result that M . musculus and M. domesticus contain more copies of YBI 0 sequences on their Y chromosome than M. abbotti, M. hortulanus and M. spretus.
body_text.section: Evolution of Y repeated segment within

body_text.text: Finally, one of the most intensely hybridizing pYBl0 fragments shared by M. musculus and M. domesticus is the 7.4-kb EcoRI fragment which is the same size as the EcoRI fragment contained in the XY6 clone identified using M720 and known to contain MuRVY sequences. This observation suggests that cookii; however, no male-specific EcoRI fragments were observed in these species (data not shown). This result suggests that none of the MuRVY-LTR-related sequences present in the genomes of these six species of mice are located on the Y chromosome. In contrast, EcoRI male-specific MuRVY-LTR-hybridizing fragments were observed in the five species M. hortulanus, M. abbotti, M. spretus, M . musculus, and M . domesticus ( Figure 8B and Table 2 ).
body_text.section: Evolution of Y repeated segment within
Evolution of Y repeated segment within

body_text.text: Comparison of the patterns of MuRVY-LTR and YB 10 male-specific hybridization fragments within each of the five species M. hortulanus, M . abbotti, M. spretus, M. musculus and M. domesticus indicates that, with few exceptions, those EcoRI fragments contain both YBlO and MuRVY sequences (Table 2 ). (The most obvious exception is the strong hybridization of the 4.3-kb EcoRI fragment to the MuRVY-LTR probe, which is due to the presence of the 3' LTR of MuRVY, K. W. HUTCHISON and E. M. EICHER, unpublished data). These data suggest that the YBlO and MuRVY sequences were present on the Y chromosome of the ancestral mouse genome that gave rise to the closely related species M. hortulanus, M. abbotti, M. spretus, M . musculus and M. domesticus in the subgenus Mus. In addition, because of the diversity of EcoRI YBl O/MuRVY-LTR positive fragments among these five species, divergence of the Y chromosomal region containing both YBlO and MuRVY occurred after speciation.
body_text.section: Evolution of Y repeated segment within

body_text.text: Amplification of the repeated segment on the Y chromosome was observed in both M. musculus and M. domesticus as evidenced by the intense hybridization of both pYBlO and pMuRVY-LTR to a 7.4-kb EcoRI fragment ( Figure 8B ). This result suggests that amplification of the repeated unit containing MuRVY and YBlO occurred in the Y chromosome of the ancestral mouse genome common to both of these species.
body_text.section: Evolution of Y repeated segment within

body_text.text: We report here the isolation and characterization of two clones containing mouse Y chromosome DNA.

These clones, designated XY6 and XY45, were initially identified in a lambda phage library of EcoRI partially digested male C57BL/10 DNA using the retrovirus M720 (PHILLIPS et al. 1982 ) as a probe. Clone XY6 contains two EcoRI fragments (7.4 kb and 4.3 kb) and clone XY45 contains five EcoRI fragments (4.3, 8.0, 0.2, 2.0 and 3.0 kb). The patterns of hybridization observed when any of the EcoRI fragments isolated from XY6 or XY45 are used to probe SOUTHERN blots containing male and female DNA suggest that each recognizes DNA sequences that are Y-specific or Yenriched and present in multiple copies on the Y chromosome. Thus, XY6 and XY45 are either of Y chromosomal origin or derived from a region of the genome that contains sequences present in multiple copies on the Y chromosome. Proof for the Y chromosomal origin of XY6 was obtained using an EcoRI/ PstI fragment (YB10) derived from the 7.4-kb EcoRI fragment as a probe to SOUTHERN blots containing EcoRI-digested female and male mouse DNA. Hybridization was observed only to male DNA. Further support for the Y chromosomal origin of XY45 was obtained by comparing its 4.3-kb EcoRI fragment with the 4.3-kb EcoRI fragment isolated from XY6. Both fragments produce the same hybridization patterns when used to probe SOUTHERN blots containing female and male DNAs and both contain M72O-related sequences. Most importantly, both fragments have identical restriction maps.

A more extensive characterization of the XY6 and XY45 clones by K. W. HUTCHISON and E. M. EICHER, unpublished data) has revealed that XY6 contains an intact retrovirus related but not identical to M720. The 5' LTR of this virus, designated MuRVY (Murine Repeated yirus on the _Ychromosome), is present in the7.4-kb EcoRI fragment of XY6 and the 3' LTR is present in the 4.3-kb EcoRI fragment of both XY6 and XY45 (Figure 2 ). DNA sequence analysis has shown that the 3' LTR present in XY6 differs in 7 out of 331-bp positions from the 3' LTR present in XY45. Although these results suggest that hY6 and XY45 are separate isolates from the mouse Y chromosome, sequence divergence within one or both LTRs of MuRVY cannot be ruled out and thus XY6 and XY45 may represent overlapping clones from the Y chromosome.

EICHER, PHILLIPS and WASHBURN (1983) have reported that the male-specific M720 and pY45/2.0 (2.0-kb EcoRI fragment isolated from XY45) ( Table  1 ) hybridizing fragments are located on the long arm of the mouse Y chromosome proximal to the region that recombines with the X chromosome.

The isolation of a Y chromosome-specific DNA sequence (YBlO) from clone XY6 offered us the opportunity to investigate the evolution of this sequence in a group of closely related species from the genus Mus.

With the exception of a faintly hybridizing band in female and male DNA derived from M. saxicola (subgenus Pyromys), we observed hybridization of YB 10 only to male DNA in a closely related group of species in the subgenus Mus, including M. spretus, M . abbotti, M. hortulanus, M. musculus and M . domesticus. In addition, we observed a species-specific pattern of hybridization for these five species. These data suggest that the YBlO sequence arose on the Mus Y chromosome after this group diverged from other species in the subgenus Mus that lack YB 10 sequences, including M. caroli, M. cervicolor and M . cookii. We suggest that the origin of the novel YBlO sequence of DNA on the Y chromosome occurred by integration of a foreign DNA sequence into the Y chromosome of the ancestor common to M. spretus, M. abbotti, M . hortulanus, M. musculus and M. domesticus and that the YB 10 species-specific patterns of hybridization observed for these five species is due to sequence divergence and amplification of YBlO during subsequent speciation events.

cite_spans.text: Mus, including M. spretus, M . abbotti, M. hortulanus, M. musculus and M . domesticus.
spretus, M. abbotti, M . hortulanus, M. musculus

body_text.text: The presence of YBIO-related sequences in female and male DNA of M. saxicola (subgenus Pyromys) may represent a convergent evolutionary event, as M. Another possibility is that a sequence related to YBlO is present in all members of the subgenus Mus but sufficient sequence divergence has occurred such that these related sequences are no longer detectable using the M. musculus-derived probe pYB10, even at the lower stringency of 79%. Analyses of other taxa in both subgenera are necessary to further elucidate the evolutionary history of YBlO in the genus Mus.

NISHIOKA and LAMOTHE (1 986) have also reported a similar presence and absence of hybridization for another Y chromosome repeated sequence in mice of the genus Mus using a Y chromosome-derived probe designated AC11. As in our study, they observed hybridization of ACl 1 to M . spretus, M . hortulanus, M. musculus and M . domesticus, and the absence of hybridization of AC11 to M. pahari, M. caroli and M. cookii. From their observations and our results, we suggest that extensive sequence divergence has taken place in the Y chromosome within the subgenus Mus.

Because both YBlO and MuRVY sequences are present in the 7.4-kb EcoRI fragment isolated from clone XY6, we investigated whether YBlO and MuRVY sequences are located within the same EcoRI fragment on the Y chromosomes of the five Mus species that contain YBlO sequences. We found that most of the YB 1 0-positive EcoRI fragments present in M. spretus, M. abbotti, M. hortulanus, M. musculus and M. domesticus contain MuRVY sequences, suggesting that the appearance of MuRVY and YBlO in the Y chromosome in this subgroup of mice occurred in a common ancestor. In addition, subsequent divergence and amplification of a DNA segment containing YBI 0 and MuRVY sequences occurred independently in the lineages leading to these five species. Because the Y chromosomes of M . musculus and M . domesticus contain multiple copies of a 7.4-kb EcoRI fragment containing YBlO and MuRVY sequences and this fragment is absent in M. spretus and M . hortulanus and present in lower copy number in M. abbotti, further amplification of this segment of Y chromosomal DNA must have occurred in the male ancestor common to M. musculus and M. domesticus. These suggestions are supported by a phylogenetic analysis using Y B 10 as a probe (TUCKER, LEE and EICHER 1989) .

Our data, combined with other data on the mouse and human Y chromosome (see reviews on molecular organization of the human Y chromosome by BISHOP et a1 1985; DAIGER and CHAKRABORTY 1985; GOOD-FELLOW, DARLING and WOLFE 1985; LAU 1985; WIL-LARD 1985) , suggest that sequence acquisition and amplification play a role in evolutionary divergence of mammalian Y chromosomes. For example, over 50% of the DNA sequences of the human Y chromosome are composed of two families of simple repeats, the HaeIII 3.4-kb (DYZ1) and HaeIII 2.1-kb (DYZ2) families (COOKE 1976) . Interestingly, neither of these repeated sequences are found on the Y chromosome of the chimpanzee or gorilla, the closest relatives of human beings, although DYZl and DYZ2 related sequences are present on autosomes in both species (COOKE, SCHMIDTKE and GOSDEN 1982; KUNKE.L and SMITH 1982) . These data imply that the DYZl and DYZ2 sequences on the human Y chromosome are derived from an integration of an autosomal sequence into the Y chromosome with subsequent amplification. As shown in this report, the Y chromosomes of five species of mice from the subgenera Mus have multiple copies of a sequence containing YBlO and MuRVY while at least three other species in this subgenera lack YBlO sequences entirely. Our data indicate that amplification of YBlO sequences together with adjacent sequences containing the retrovirus MuRVY occurred independently in the lineages leading to M. spretus, M . abbotti and M. hortulanus, as well as the lineages leading to M . musculus and M. domesticus. In the latter two species, further amplification of these sequences occurred such that their Y chromosomes contain approximately 500 copies of this repeated sequence. For example, estimates of the copy number of the XY6 7.4-kb EcoRI fragment present in C57BL/ lOJ male genomic DNA indicate that it is present in 500 copies and accounts for approximately 5.5% of the DNA constituting the Y chromosome. Certainly, such integration and amplification of DNA sequences on the Y chromosomes of man and mouse argues that this is a common method for rapid evolution of the mammalian Y chromosome.

From data gathered to date on the DNA content and organization of the murine and human Y chromosomes we propose that the mammalian Y chromosome of closely related species will contain fewer homologous DNA sequences than might have been previously predicted because the mammalian Y chromosome is more "free" to lose, gain, and amplify DNA sequences than are chromosomes that must pair and recombine in a "side-by-side'' manner with their homolog during meiosis. Thus, as a whole the mammalian Y chromosome may be evolving at a faster rate than are the other mammalian chromosomes. If we are correct, then low copy number Y-specific sequences that hybridize to Y chromosomal DNA from distantly related mammalian species are perhaps the only sequences that the Y chromosome requires to ensure its retention by the mammalian genome. Some of these sequences will include centromere-and telemere-related sequences which are necessary for successful transmission during cell division, pairing and recombination sequences which are necessary to guarantee segregation from the X chromosome during male meiosis, and sequences involved in primary sex determination.

FIGREF8.text: Mus species: SOUTHERN blots containing EcoRI-digested genomic DNAs from both females and males of representative species of the four subgenera of Mus were probed with pYBIO. These species included M. saxicola (subgenus Pyromys); M. pahari (subgenus Coelom y ) ; M . minutoides (subgenus Nannomys); and M. caroli, M. ceruicolor, M. cookii, M. spretus, M . hortulanus, M. musculus, M. domesticus and M. abbotti (subgenus Mus). T h e results are shown in Figure 7. With the exception of a single fragment observed in both female and male DNA of M . saxicola, hybridization to pY B 10 was observed only to male DNA of five species: M. spretus, M. hortulanus, M. musculus, M. domesticus and M. abbotti. We conclude that, with the exception of M. saxicola, the YBlO sequence is present only on the Y chromosome in a closely related subgroup of the subgenus Mus, including M. spretus, M. hortulanus, M . musculus, M. domesticus and M. abbotti. A SOUTHERN blot containing EcoRI digested DNAs from representative males of the five species M. spretus, M. hortulanus, M. abbotti, M. domesticus and M. musculus probed with pYBl0 is shown in

An (*) designates pYBl0 hybridizing fragments known to be polymorphic among members of the species (TUCKER, LEE and EICHER 1989).

Further support for this hypothesis was cjbtained with the following experiment. SOUTHERN blots containing 10 pg of EcoRI digested DNA obtained from females and males of M. saxicola, M . pahari, M. minutoides, M. caroli, M. cervicolor, M. cookii, M. hortulanus, M. abbotti, M . spretus, M. musculus and M. domesticus were probed with pMuRVY-LTR, an M13mp8 subclone containing the LTR of MuRVY (K. W. HUTCHISON and E. M. EICHER, unpublished data). The pMuRVY-LTR probe hybridized to EcoRI fragments derived from females and males of the species M . saxicola, M. pahari, M. minutoides, M . caroli, M. cervicolor and M.

FIGREF12.text: saxicola is considered to be more distantly related to M . spretus, M. abbotti, M. hortulanus, M. musculus and M. domesticus than are M . caroli, M. cervicolor and M. cookii (MARSHALL 1977). An alternative interpretation is that the YBlO sequence arose in an ancestor common to the subgenera Mus and Pyromys and was subsequently lost in M . caroli, M . cervicolor and M. cookii and restricted to the Y chromosome in a common ancestor to M. spretus, M. abbotti, M. hortulanus, M. musculus and M. domesticus.
